docs.title: 🐍 ViperX
docs.text: Stop wasting time on project setup. Start coding in 30 seconds.

docs.title: The Problem
docs.text:
Every time you start a new Python project, you face the same tedious questions:

  • "How do I structure this properly?"
  • "What goes in pyproject.toml?"
  • "Where should I put my config files so Colab can find them?"
  • "Do I need .env at root or in the package?"

ViperX solves this. One command, one config file, done.

docs.title: The Solution: viperx.yaml
docs.text:
Instead of memorizing CLI flags, just describe what you want:

# viperx.yaml
project:
  name: "churn-predictor"
  description: "Customer churn prediction model"

settings:
  type: "ml"          # ML project with notebooks
  use_env: true       # I need secrets

Then run:

viperx config get     # Generate template (optional)
viperx config -c viperx.yaml

That's it. You get:

churn_predictor/
├── pyproject.toml    # Ready to go
├── notebooks/        # Jupyter ready
├── data/             # For datasets
└── src/churn_predictor/
    ├── main.py       # Entry point
    ├── config.py     # Works on Colab!
    └── .env          # Isolated, safe

docs.title: Why ViperX?
docs.text: Problem ViperX Solution "My config breaks on Colab" Config lives inside your package ".env leaks between projects" .env is isolated in src/pkg/ "I forgot what flags I used" viperx.yaml is your single source of truth "Updating breaks my project" Safe Mode: ViperX never deletes files

docs.title: CLI Reference
docs.text:
For those who prefer the command line.

We recommend viperx.yaml

While CLI flags work great for quick projects, viperx.yaml is better for:

  • Reproducibility
  • Team sharing
  • Complex projects

docs.title: Main Command: viperx config
docs.text:
This is the primary command. It can: - Create new projects - Update existing projects - Apply config files

# Declarative (recommended)
viperx config -c viperx.yaml

# Imperative (quick & dirty)
viperx config -n my-project -t ml --env

docs.title: All Options
docs.text: Flag Short What it does --name -n Project name --type -t classic, ml, dl --description -d Project description --author -a Author name --license -l MIT, Apache-2.0, GPLv3 --builder -b uv, hatch --framework -f pytorch, tensorflow --env Generate .env --no-env No .env (default) --config -c Path to viperx.yaml

docs.title: Alias: viperx init
docs.text:
Same as viperx config. Use whichever feels natural:

viperx init -n my-project
# Same as
viperx config -n my-project

docs.title: viperx config get
docs.text:
Generates a template viperx.yaml in current directory.

viperx config get
# Creates viperx.yaml with all options commented

docs.title: config update - Rebuild from Reality
docs.text:
viperx config update

Scans your existing codebase and updates viperx.yaml: - Detects packages in src/ - Detects use_config, use_env, use_tests from actual files - Adds inline annotations (# NOT_APPLIED) for conflicts - Safe: Never deletes lines, only adds or updates

docs.title: Configuration Deep Dive
docs.text: The viperx.yaml file is your project's DNA.

docs.title: The Problem with CLI Flags
docs.text:
# Week 1: You run this
viperx init -n my-proj -t ml --env -l Apache-2.0 -b hatch

# Week 4: You need another project
# "What flags did I use again?"

docs.title: The Solution
docs.text:
# viperx.yaml - Always here, always clear
project:
  name: "my-proj"
  license: "Apache-2.0"
  builder: "hatch"

settings:
  type: "ml"
  use_env: true

docs.title: project Section
docs.text: Key What it does Default name Your project name Required description Shows in PyPI "" author Package author git user license MIT, Apache-2.0, GPLv3 MIT builder uv or hatch uv

docs.title: settings Section
docs.text: Key What it does Default type classic, ml, dl classic framework pytorch, tensorflow (DL only) pytorch use_env Generate .env file false use_config Generate config.py true use_tests Generate tests/ folder true

docs.title: Minimal (Just the basics)
docs.text:
project:
  name: "my-lib"

docs.title: Full ML Project
docs.text:
project:
  name: "churn-model"
  description: "Customer churn prediction"
  author: "Data Science Team"
  license: "Apache-2.0"

docs.title: Multi-package Platform
docs.text:
project:
  name: "my-platform"

settings:
  use_tests: true

workspace:
  packages:
    - name: "api"
      type: "classic"
    - name: "model"
      type: "ml"
      use_env: true      # Only model needs secrets
    - name: "worker"
      type: "classic"
      use_tests: false   # No tests for worker

docs.title: Applying Your Config
docs.text:
# First time: Creates everything
viperx config -c viperx.yaml

# Later: Updates safely (adds missing, never deletes)
viperx config -c viperx.yaml

docs.title: Safe Mode: What Happens on Update?
docs.text:
You change... ViperX does... use_env: false → true ✅ Creates .env use_env: true → false ⚠️ Warns you .env exists (doesn't delete) Add new package ✅ Creates it Remove package from yaml ⚠️ Warns you folder exists (doesn't delete) Change license ⚠️ Warns you LICENSE differs (doesn't overwrite)

Philosophy: ViperX will never destroy your work.

docs.title: Conflict Transparency
docs.text:
If your viperx.yaml disagrees with reality (e.g., config says use_env: false but .env exists), ViperX will: 1. NOT delete the file 2. Annotate the conflict in viperx.yaml:

use_env: false  # NOT_APPLIED: file exists in codebase

This ensures you have total transparency on the state of your project.

docs.title: Generating a Template
docs.text:
viperx config get

Creates a commented viperx.yaml with all options explained.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: Time to install: 30 seconds

docs.title: The Problem
docs.text: You want ViperX available globally, without polluting your project's dependencies.

docs.title: Option 1: pipx (Recommended)
docs.text:
pipx install viperx

Why pipx? - Isolated environment (no conflicts) - Available everywhere - Easy to upgrade

docs.title: Option 2: uv tool
docs.text:
uv tool install viperx

Why uv? - If you're already using uv (you should!) - Same isolation benefits

docs.title: 📦 Publishing Guide: Beyond PyPI
docs.text: Releasing to PyPI (pip install) is the basics. To be a professional tool, you need to be where your users are: Homebrew (macOS) and Conda (Data Science).

docs.title: 🍺 Homebrew Tap (The "Hacker" Standard)
docs.text: Users expect brew install your-tool. To do this without waiting for months for Homebrew Core acceptance, create a Personal Tap.

docs.title: Step 1: Create the Repo
docs.text: Create a public GitHub repository named EXACTLY homebrew-viperx. (Or homebrew-commands, but homebrew-viperx allows brew tap kpihx/viperx).

docs.title: Step 2: The Formula
docs.text:
Create a file viperx.rb in that repo:

class Viperx < Formula
  include Language::Python::Virtualenv

  desc "Professional Python Project Initializer with uv & config-as-code"
  homepage "https://github.com/KpihX/viperx"
  url "https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/.../viperx-1.4.0.tar.gz" # Get this from PyPI
  sha256 "..." # Get this from PyPI (at the hash link)
  license "MIT"

  depends_on "python@3.12"
  depends_on "uv" # Optional, if you want to enforce uv presence

  def install
    virtualenv_install_with_resources
  end

  test do
    system "#{bin}/viperx", "--version"
  end
end

docs.title: Step 3: Usage
docs.text:
Users can now run: 

brew tap kpihx/viperx
brew install viperx
Boom. You look like a pro.

docs.title: 🐍 Conda Forge (The Science Standard)
docs.text: For Data Scientists, conda install viperx is mandatory.

docs.title: Step 1: Fork & Recipe
docs.text:
1. Fork conda-forge/staged-recipes.
  2. Create a folder recipes/viperx/.
  3. Add meta.yaml:
{% set name = "viperx" %}
{% set version = "1.4.0" %}

package:
  name: {{ name|lower }}
  version: {{ version }}

source:
  url: https://pypi.io/packages/source/{{ name[0] }}/{{ name }}/{{ name }}-{{ version }}.tar.gz
  sha256: ...

build:
  number: 0
  noarch: python
  script: {{ PYTHON }} -m pip install . -vv

requirements:
  host:
    - python >=3.8
    - pip
  run:
    - python >=3.8
    - typer
    - rich
    - jinja2
    - pyyaml
    - tomlkit

test:
  imports:
    - viperx
  commands:
    - viperx --help

about:
  home: https://github.com/KpihX/viperx
  license: MIT
  summary: 'Professional Python Project Initializer'

docs.title: Step 2: Pull Request
docs.text: Submit the PR to staged-recipes. A bot will check it. Once merged, the viperx feedstock is created automatically, and you are on channel conda-forge.

docs.title: 🐧 AUR (Arch Linux)
docs.text:
For the brave. Create a PKGBUILD.

# Maintainer: KpihX <...>
pkgname=viperx
pkgver=1.4.0
pkgrel=1
pkgdesc="Professional Python Project Initializer"
arch=('any')
url="https://github.com/KpihX/viperx"
license=('MIT')
depends=('python' 'python-typer' 'python-rich' 'python-jinja' 'python-yaml' 'python-tomlkit')
source=("https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/source/v/viperx/viperx-$pkgver.tar.gz")
sha256sums=('...')

build() {
  cd "$pkgname-$pkgver"
  python -m build --wheel --no-isolation
}

package() {
  cd "$pkgname-$pkgver"
  python -m installer --destdir="$pkgdir" dist/*.whl
}
Submit to aur.archlinux.org.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Goal: Go from zero to running project in 5 minutes.

docs.title: Scenario 1: "I just want a simple library"
docs.text:
The problem: You need a clean Python package, properly structured, with tests.

The solution:

viperx config get

This creates a viperx.yaml template. Edit it:

project:
  name: "my-utils"
  description: "My utility library"

Apply:

viperx config -c viperx.yaml
cd my_utils
uv sync
uv run my-utils
# Output: Hi from my-utils!

What you get: - ✅ Proper src/ layout - ✅ pyproject.toml ready for PyPI - ✅ Tests folder - ✅ CLI entry point

docs.title: Scenario 2: "I'm building a Kaggle model"
docs.text:
The problem: You need: - Notebooks that can access your config - A data folder for datasets - Secrets for API keys

The solution:

# viperx.yaml
project:
  name: "titanic-survival"
  description: "Kaggle Titanic competition"

settings:
  type: "ml"
  use_env: true

viperx config -c viperx.yaml

What you get:

titanic_survival/
├── notebooks/
│   ├── Base_Kaggle.ipynb    # Kaggle-ready!
│   └── Base_General.ipynb   # Local development
├── data/                    # Dataset caching
└── src/titanic_survival/
    ├── config.py            # Works on Colab/Kaggle!
    ├── .env                  # Your KAGGLE_KEY here
    └── data_loader.py        # Smart caching

Why this works on Kaggle/Colab:

# In your notebook:
from titanic_survival import SETTINGS, get_config

# This works because config is INSIDE the package
print(SETTINGS['project_name'])

docs.title: Scenario 3: "I need PyTorch for deep learning"
docs.text:
The problem: You want all the ML stuff plus: - PyTorch dependencies - GPU setup hints - Model structure

The solution:

project:
  name: "vision-transformer"
  description: "ViT from scratch"

settings:
  type: "dl"
  framework: "pytorch"
  use_env: true

viperx config -c viperx.yaml

What you get: - torch>=2.5.0 in dependencies - torchvision>=0.21.0 included - Same notebook + data structure

docs.title: Scenario 4: "I have multiple related packages"
docs.text:
The problem: You're building a platform with: - An API service - A ML model - A worker

The solution:

project:
  name: "my-platform"
  description: "Full stack ML platform"

workspace:
  packages:
    - name: "api"
      type: "classic"
    - name: "model"
      type: "ml"
      use_env: true
    - name: "worker"
      type: "classic"

viperx config -c viperx.yaml

What you get:

my_platform/
├── pyproject.toml       # All scripts registered
└── src/
    ├── my_platform/     # Root package
    ├── api/             # API service
    ├── model/           # ML with .env
    └── worker/          # Background jobs

Run any package:

uv run api
uv run model
uv run worker

docs.title: The Alternative: CLI Flags
docs.text:
Don't like config files? Use flags:

# Quick classic project
viperx init -n my-lib

# ML project with .env
viperx init -n my-model -t ml --env

# DL with TensorFlow
viperx init -n tf-project -t dl -f tensorflow

But we recommend viperx.yaml because: - You can version it - You can share it with teammates - You won't forget what options you used

  3. Run tests to verify

docs.title: Workspaces
docs.text: The Problem: You have multiple related packages (API, ML model, worker). The Solution: One project, multiple packages, shared config.

docs.title: When Do You Need a Workspace?
docs.text: Situation Workspace? Single library or app ❌ No ML model + API together ✅ Yes Monorepo with shared code ✅ Yes Microservices in one repo ✅ Yes

docs.title: Step 1: Define Your Structure
docs.text:
# viperx.yaml
project:
  name: "ml-platform"
  description: "ML Platform with API"

workspace:
  packages:
    - name: "api"
      type: "classic"
      description: "REST API"

    - name: "model"
      type: "ml"
      use_env: true
      description: "ML prediction model"

    - name: "worker"
      type: "classic"
      description: "Background jobs"

docs.title: Step 2: Apply
docs.text: viperx config -c viperx.yaml

docs.title: Step 3: What You Get
docs.text:
ml_platform/
├── pyproject.toml        # All packages registered
├── viperx.yaml           # Your config
├── notebooks/            # From ML package
├── data/                 # Shared data folder
└── src/
    ├── ml_platform/      # Root package
    │   └── main.py
    ├── api/
    │   └── main.py
    ├── model/
    │   ├── main.py
    │   └── .env          # Only here (isolated!)
    └── worker/
        └── main.py

docs.title: Running Your Packages
docs.text:
Each package gets its own CLI command:

uv sync

# Run any package
uv run ml-platform    # Root
uv run api            # API service
uv run model          # ML model
uv run worker         # Worker

docs.title: Why .env is Isolated
docs.text:
The Problem: In a multi-package setup, you might have: - model/ needs OPENAI_KEY - api/ needs DB_PASSWORD - worker/ needs REDIS_URL

If .env was at root: All packages see all secrets (security risk).

With ViperX: Each .env lives in its own package:

src/
├── api/.env         # DB_PASSWORD only
├── model/.env       # OPENAI_KEY only
└── worker/.env      # REDIS_URL only

docs.title: Package Inheritance
docs.text:
Packages inherit settings from root unless overridden:

settings:
  use_tests: true      # Default for all

workspace:
  packages:
    - name: "api"
      # Inherits use_tests: true

    - name: "scripts"
      use_tests: false  # Override: no tests

docs.title: Adding Packages Later
docs.text:
Project evolves? Add packages anytime:

viperx package add -n analytics -t ml --env

Or update viperx.yaml and re-apply:

workspace:
  packages:
    - name: "api"
    - name: "model"
    - name: "analytics"    # New!

viperx config -c viperx.yaml
# Only creates analytics/, doesn't touch others

docs.title: Removing Packages
docs.text:
ViperX won't delete your code. If you remove a package from yaml:

viperx config -c viperx.yaml
# Warning: src/old-package/ exists but is not in config
# You need to delete it manually if you want

This is Safe Mode in action.
